title: DirectFB
text:
DirectFB (Direct Frame Buffer) is a <a href="Library%20%28computing%29">software library</a> with a small <a href="memory%20footprint">memory footprint</a> that provides <a href="graphics%20acceleration">graphics acceleration</a>, <a href="input%20device">input device</a> handling and <a href="abstraction%20layer">abstraction layer</a>, and integrated <a href="windowing%20system">windowing system</a> with support for translucent windows and multiple display layers on top of the <a href="Linux%20framebuffer">Linux framebuffer</a> without requiring any <a href="kernel%20%28operating%20system%29">kernel</a> modifications. DirectFB is <a href="free%20and%20open-source%20software">free and open-source software</a> subject to the terms of the <a href="GNU%20Lesser%20General%20Public%20License">GNU Lesser General Public License</a> (LGPL).
The library allows developers an alternative to a full <a href="X%20Window%20System">X Window System</a> (X11) server used in <a href="Unix-like">Unix-like</a> <a href="operating%20system">operating system</a>s. DirectFB allows applications to talk directly to video hardware through a direct <a href="Application%20programming%20interface">API</a>, speeding up and simplifying graphic operations.
It is often used by <a href="Video%20game">games</a> and <a href="embedded%20system">embedded system</a>s developers to circumvent the overhead of a full <a href="X%20Window%20System">X Window System</a> server implementation. In 2006, a version of DirectFB was included in the software stack for the <a href="CE%20Linux%20Forum">CE Linux Forum</a>'s Audio/Video Graphics Specification V2.
DirectFB can host <a href="XDirectFB">XDirectFB</a>, a rootless X server implementation that uses DirectFB windows for X11 top-level windows. XDirectFB is an interface that mimics the X11 interface through the DirectFB API to simplify running applications written for X11 on DirectFB.
<a href="DirectFBGL">DirectFBGL</a> is an <a href="OpenGL">OpenGL</a> extension for DirectFB/XDirectFB that uses <a href="Direct%20Rendering%20Infrastructure">Direct Rendering Infrastructure</a> (DRI) in the <a href="Mesa%203D">Mesa 3D</a> library to support OpenGL hardware acceleration.
Among the products that use DirectFB are <a href="LinuxTV">LinuxTV</a>, <a href="Ben%20Nanonote">Ben Nanonote</a>, the unreleased <a href="Palm%20Foleo">Palm Foleo</a> mobile companion, the <a href="webOS">webOS</a> operating system, Panasonic Viera Connect TVs and the <a href="Philips">Philips</a> TVs based on jointSPACE.
